customer_name: Animals for Education - Critter Creek Wildlife Station
customer_addr:
36710 Sand Creek Road
Squaw Valley, CA 93675

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
In the Infirmary used for both rehabilitation and exhibit animals, a medication cabinet used primarily for rehabilitation
purposes per the Licensee, but not labelled for this purpose, contained many medications that were either not adequately
labeled and/or were out of date. In a second medication cabinet, also not labelled, but its stated use was exhibit animals
only per the Licensee, there was a container of Ivermectin that expired 11/2016. Medical supplies that are not properly
labeled and/or not properly stored, could deteriorate, become contaminated, or be misused, possibly resulting in harm to
the health and well-being of the animals. Medicines used to prevent or treat disease must be properly stored, labeled, and
not expired in order for them to appropriately and effectively prevent, control, and/or treat diseases.
Correct by: 03/13/2024

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
Two burrowing owls which had been acquired by the facility were not able to be shown to the APHIS inspector. The
facility reported they normally observe the owls in the morning during feeding but the owls were currently down in their
burrows at the time of inspection. Multiple attempts were made with a flexible endoscope camera to find the birds in the
burrows but the animals could not be located. Additional burrows had been dug by the owls and after several attempts
with endoscope was still unable to find them. If inspectors are not given the opportunity to visually inspect an animal then
it is not possible to evaluate that animals welfare. Each exhibitor shall, during business hours, allow APHIS officials to
inspect and photograph the facilities, property and animals to enforce the provisions of the Act, the regulations and the
standards.
Correct by: 03/13/2024

The kitchen/food prep area was dirty and had a layer of dust on the counters over the sink and spider webs with dead flies
that extended over the food stage shelves. Additionally, Radiology had 4 stainless steel cages that were full of
spiderwebs, old dried bird droppings, dried feces, and had not been cleaned and/or sanitized. These areas need to be
cleaned and organized to ensure that food and food receptacles cannot be contaminated during cleaning and/or
preparation.
Correct by: 03/13/2024

A number of enclosures had sharp points present:
There were broken wooden slats with points sharp edges pointing into the cage and the raised nail heads in the enclosure
with 6 Red Tailed Hawks and 5 Turkey Vultures.
There were wire ties pointing into the Scrub Jay enclosure.
There were raised screw heads and nail heads in the Enclosure containing 5 Red Shouldered Hawks.
There was a broken screw in the perch of enclosure containing 7 Common Ravens
All of the birds were free in each of their enclosures with access to the sharp points. The primary enclosure must be
constructed and maintained so that they have no sharp points that could potentially injure the birds.
Correct by: 03/13/2024

In an outdoor enclosure, 2 American Kestrels had access to unprotected power cords that were plugged into live outlets.
This could lead to potential electrocution and or injury if the bird were to damage the exposed cords. Additionally in a flight
cage containing 6 Red-Tailed hawks and 5 Turkey Vultures several vertical wall slats that were not installed in parallel
creating potential constricting points for toes. One pinch point was approximately 1.5inchs at the top and was touching at
the bottom. Primary enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury.
Correct by: 03/13/2024

In the Great horned owl enclosure, Golden Eagle Exhibit, Bald Eagles enclosure, Swainson’s Hawks enclosure, Barn Owl
Enclosure, Red-Shouldered Hawk Exhibit Cage, Screech-owl/Burrowing Owl enclosure, Red-Shouldered Hawk
enclosure, Coopers Hawk/Peregrine Falcon/Prairie Falcon Enclosure, and American Crow enclosure had many walls with
exposed damaged plywood and/or particleboard that was not able to be effectively cleaned and sanitized. Primary
enclosures must be constructed and maintained so that all surfaces in contact with the birds may be readily cleaned
and/or sanitized in accordance with 3.158 or be replaced when worn or soiled.
Correct by: 04/29/2024

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The facility did not have a documented environment enhancement plan to promote psychological well-being of their avian
species as required by the Animal Welfare Act. The facility must develop, document and follow a species appropriate plan
for environmental enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by
the attending veterinarian, and at a minimum must address social grouping, environmental enrichment, special
considerations, restraint, and exemptions to the plan regulation and be in accordance with currently accepted professional
standards.
Correct by: 03/13/2024

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
Five primary enclosures, housing a total of 22 birds, were dirty with a buildup of wet excrement, food waste, and spider
webs covering the walls and floors. Insufficient cleaning can lead to disease hazards, insects, pest and odors. Excreta
and food waste must be removed from within, under, and around the primary enclosure often enough to prevent
excessive accumulation.
Correct by: 03/13/2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Facility Representative.
n
